articles.title: Russia Launches Largest Air Attack on Ukraine Capital
articles.summary: Russia conducted its biggest aerial assault on Ukraine, striking a government building in Kyiv for the first time. Three people died including a mother and baby during the attack that targeted the Ukrainian capital with unprecedented force, marking a significant escalation in the ongoing conflict.

articles.title: Japanese Prime Minister Ishiba Announces Resignation Plans
articles.summary: Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to resign to prevent division within Japan's Liberal Democratic Party after losing the Upper House majority in July elections. His departure follows mounting pressure from party rivals seeking new leadership amid political instability in the nation.

articles.title: Iran Offers Nuclear Monitoring Deal for Sanctions Relief
articles.summary: Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi proposed exchanging enhanced nuclear monitoring for lifted economic sanctions, urging European powers to change course and negotiate a new agreement. The diplomatic initiative represents Tehran's latest attempt to resolve the nuclear standoff with Western nations through renewed dialogue.

articles.title: EU Hits Google with Record Adtech Antitrust Fine
articles.summary: The European Commission fined Google ‚Ç¨2.95 billion for violating antitrust rules by favoring its AdX advertising exchange through dominant positions in publisher ad servers and buying tools. Google has sixty days to end these self-preferencing practices or face additional penalties.

articles.title: Mozambique Secures World Bank Support for Mega Dam
articles.summary: Mozambique received World Bank backing for a six billion dollar hydroelectric plant, southern Africa's largest energy project in fifty years. The massive infrastructure development promises to transform the region's power generation capacity and boost economic growth across multiple neighboring countries.

articles.title: OPEC Plus Announces Major Oil Production Increase
articles.summary: OPEC Plus members agreed to boost oil output by 1.66 million barrels daily, marking a significant shift in production strategy. The decision reflects changing global energy demands and market conditions as the alliance adjusts its supply management approach for international petroleum markets.

articles.title: Japanese Firm Pioneers Revolutionary Carbon Capture Technology
articles.summary: NGK Insulators developed breakthrough ceramic technology for removing carbon dioxide directly from air, positioning Japan at the forefront of climate solutions. The innovation promises to revolutionize industrial carbon capture as the world accelerates away from fossil fuel dependence toward sustainable alternatives.

articles.title: Breakthrough Lung Cancer Treatment Shows Exceptional Survival Rates
articles.summary: Johnson and Johnson's combination therapy of Rybrevant plus Lazcluze demonstrated projected survival exceeding four years for EGFR-mutated lung cancer patients. Published in The New England Journal of Medicine, the chemotherapy-free regimen significantly outperforms standard monotherapy treatments in first-line care.

articles.title: Immigration Raid at Hyundai Plant Detains Korean Workers
articles.summary: Over three hundred South Korean workers were arrested during an immigration raid at Hyundai's electric vehicle plant in Georgia. Officials confirmed the detained workers will be released and flown home, highlighting tensions around foreign labor at major manufacturing facilities in America.

articles.title: Deep Sea Mining Sparks Global Environmental Debate
articles.summary: A yellow robot deployed into the Pacific Ocean highlights intensifying disputes over deep-sea mining for critical minerals. The controversial practice promises essential materials for green technology but raises serious environmental concerns about disturbing pristine ocean ecosystems thousands of meters below the surface.
